messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 53 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Graph-Based Semi-Supervised Segregated Lipschitz Learning

Paper Abstract: Abstract. This paper presents an approach to semi-supervised learning for the classification of data using the Lipschitz Learning on graphs. We develop a graph-based semi-supervised learning framework that leverages the properties of the infinity Laplacian to propagate labels in a dataset where only a few samples are labeled. By extending the theory of spatial segregation from the Laplace operator to the infinity Laplace operator, both in continuum and discrete settings, our approach provides a robust method for dealing with class imbalance, a common challenge in machine learning. Experimental validation on several benchmark datasets demonstrates that our method not only improves classification accuracy compared to existing methods but also ensures efficient label propagation in scenarios with limited labeled data.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 53 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 53"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Learning on graph with laplacian regularization",
        "Minimization problems for the functional supxf‚Äã(x,f‚Äã(x),f‚Ä≤‚Äã(x))subscriptsupremumùë•ùëìùë•ùëìùë•superscriptùëì‚Ä≤ùë•\\sup_{x}f(x,f(x),f^{\\prime}(x))",
        "Extension of functions satisfying lipschitz conditions",
        "A tour of the theory of absolutely minimizing functions",
        "The infinity laplacian, aronsson‚Äôs equation and their generalizations",
        "Using manifold structure for partially labeled classification",
        "Diffuse interface models on graphs for classification of high dimensional data",
        "The infinity laplacian eigenvalue problem: Reformulation and a numerical scheme",
        "Graph based semisupervised learning using spatial segregation theory",
        "Classification and image processing with a semi-discrete scheme for fidelity forced allen‚Äìcahn on graphs",
        "The convergence rate of pùëùp-harmonic to infinity-harmonic functions",
        "Uniform convergence rates for lipschitz learning on graphs",
        "The game theoretic pùëùp-laplacian and semi-supervised learning with few labels",
        "Consistency of lipschitz learning with infinite unlabeled data and finite labeled data",
        "Poisson learning: Graph based semi-supervised learning at very low label rates",
        "A h√∂lder infinity laplacian",
        "Graph-based semi-supervised learning: A review",
        "A variational problem for the spatial segregation of reaction-diffusion systems",
        "A visit with the ‚àû\\infty-laplace equation",
        "Optimal lipschitz extensions and the infinity laplacian",
        "Uniqueness of ‚àû\\infty-harmonic functions and the eikonal equation",
        "Keel data-mining software tool: Data set repository, integration of algorithms and experimental analysis framework",
        "Eikonal equation adaptation on weighted graphs: fast geometric diffusion process for local and non-local image and data processing",
        "Asymptotic behavior of ‚Ñìpsubscript‚Ñìùëù\\ell_{p}-based laplacian regularization in semi-supervised learning",
        "Continuum limit of p-laplacian evolution problems on graphs: Lq graphons and sparse graphs",
        "On the connection between tug-of-war games and nonlocal pdes on graphs",
        "Nonlocal infinity laplacian equation on graphs with applications in image processing and machine learning",
        "On the game pùëùp-laplacian on weighted graphs with applications in image processing and data clustering",
        "Nonlocal pdes on graphs: From tug-of-war games to unified interpolation on images and point clouds",
        "On the pùëùp-laplacian and ‚àû\\infty-laplacian on graphs with applications in image and data processing",
        "Augmented Lagrangian methods for degenerate Hamilton-Jacobi equations",
        "Tug of war games and pdes on graphs with applications in image and high dimensional data processing",

        "Multiclass data segmentation using diffuse interface methods on graphs",

        "On the evolution governed by the infinity laplacian",
        "The ‚àû\\infty-eigenvalue problem",
        "Siamese neural networks for one-shot image recognition",
        "Algorithms for lipschitz learning on graphs",
        "Dynamic programming principle for tug-of-war games with noise",
        "On the definition and properties of pùëùp-harmonious functions",
        "Gradient flows in metric random walk spaces",
        "Variational and diffusion problems in random walk spaces",
        "Cahn‚Äìhilliard equations on random walk spaces",
        "An mbo scheme on graphs for classification and image processing",
        "Semi-supervised learning with the graph laplacian: The limit of infinite unlabelled data",
        "Digitized pde method for data restoration",
        "Extensions Lipschitziennes minimales",
        "An mbo scheme for minimizing the graph ohta‚Äìkawasaki functional",
        "Mean curvature, threshold dynamics, and phase field theory on finite graphs",
        "Learning similarity with cosine similarity ensemble",
        "Semi-supervised learning using gaussian fields and harmonic functions"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 53 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Graph-Based Semi-Supervised Segregated Lipschitz Learning, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
